awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Computation of accurate binding energies of emerging organic contaminants on environmental and infrastructural interfaces
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This RAPID project was executed in response to the January 9, 2014, Freedom Industries chemical spill into the Elk River in West Virginia. Among other properties, the fate and transport behavior of the “spilled fluid” constituents was poorly understood or unknown. Faced with this dearth of information, once it was discovered that these compounds had contaminated the water supply a "Do Not Use Order" was issued for 300,000 people in nine West Virginia counties. The overarching goals of our project are to provide quick and accurate computational methods that may aid in decision making when poorly characterized contaminants are released.
This project aimed to investigate quantum chemical computational methods to provide binding energies of all the major crude MCHM and PPh components with simple models of polymer surfaces used in domestic water systems, environmental interfaces prevalent in silts and clays, and materials used within water processing filtration. To approach these goals, extensive investigation into efficient computational methods and the influence of contaminant conformational complexity on physicochemical properties was investigated.
This RAPID grant provides a foundation to develop models predictive models of binding energies of future emerging contaminants with surfaces of environmental and infrastructural importance. Our efforts will build to a toolkit allowing emergency responders to obtain on-demand and on-the-fly estimates of the behavior of these contaminants and can help direct remediation or prevention strategies on the ground in a timely manner in future incidents.
Intellectual Merit
Extended polymer and amorphous carbon models were constructed and will be included in a database for future studies on contaminant binding. Data analysis and reporting are in progress relative to these goals and will continue beyond this project timeline. 
Binding energies of MCHM have been computed using small "proof of concept" models of silane and small silica clusters. The small model size allows energy computation at a highly accurate level of theory. Data for determining dimerization and trimerization energies MCHM was obtained to compare the contaminant aggregation energy against the surface binding energy. Data analysis and reporting are in progress relative to these goals and will continue beyond this project timeline. 
Using the known organic contaminants in the Elk River spill, as well as a database of benzene and cyclohexane derivatives found in published solubility compendia, various computational chemistry methodologies have been calibrated against experimentally known values. Information was compiled on the influence of electronic correlation and basis sets in computing physical properties of cyclohexane and benzene derivatives. These results help reveal optimum time-cost vs. accuracy of various methods. We pinpointed specific methodology (MP2 aug-cc-pVDZ) that can provide a) accurate relative conformational energies, b) accurate Boltzmann-averaged NMR spectra, and c) accurate dipole moments in a reasonable amount of computing time. The results provided by this level of theory are reliable and can provide a solid benchmark for quicker "first response" computational methods.
Ensuring accuracy in computational prediction of physicochemical properties using rapid quantum chemical methods requires accounting for conformational flexibility. We used stochastic conformational search algorithms and Boltzmann-averaging to incorporate this flexibility of the Elk River spill contaminants in our computations. Two papers detailing our determination of the molar volume and dipole moment of cis and trans MCHM, including proper conformational and thermal averaging, have been published in the journals Environmental Science and Technology Letters, and Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics. The work was featured on the cover of ES&T Letters.

Broader Impacts
Through coordination with the NSF RAPID Elk River team, our input has been invaluable for validating solubility schemes. Interdisciplinary collaborations have blossomed between types of researchers that rarely overlap, i.e. those focused on the microscopic world (quantum chemists) versus those focused on the macroscopic world (environmental engineers). 
Multiple students, including underrepresented minorities and military veterans, at the graduate, undergraduate, and high school levels were introduced and fully participated in computational chemistry research, increasing their STEM professional preparedness.
Alexander co-organized the NSF-sponsored “Fostering Advances in Water Resource Protection and Crisis Communication, Lessons Learned from Recent Disasters" workshop in May 2015 in Shepherdstown, WV, bringing together all NSF RAPID funding PIs responsive to the Elk River and Dan River spills. Alexander and DeYonker contributed to a manuscript that suggests policy changes and new formal mechanisms to improve scientific response to chemical spills in the Journal of Environmental Quality.
 
Alexander organized, presided, and presented in a half-day symposium at the 251st ACS National Meeting in San Diego, CA in March 2016. The symposium “Opportunities & Progress in Computational Prediction of Contaminant Toxicity, Fate & Transport Properties” brought together diverse researchers from academia, industry, and government organizations. NSF RAPID research was highlighted.
Results were disseminated through over a dozen poster and oral presentations at local, regional, and national conferences and universities. Thus far efforts have resulted in four published peer-reviewed journal articles with more planned and in-progress. These papers are available at:doi.org/10.1021/acs.estlett.5b00061; doi.org/10.1016/j.comptc.2015.09.008; doi.org/10.1039/C5CP05952F; doi.org/10.2134/jeq2016.03.0090
